Award.AwardTitle: EAGER:Field Testing Two New Portable Geothermal Gradient Probe Prototypes
Award.AbstractNarration:
For the past sixty years or so, scientists have been collecting heat flow data from the seafloor using large, heavy instruments that are inserted into the sediment and measure temperature versus depth below the seafloor. Heat flow data provide fundamental information on the physical, chemical and biological processes that are occurring near and below the seafloor and ultimately, information on the thermal and chemical evolution of Earth. The goal of this study is to advance the development of two prototype heat probes beyond the testing/development stage so that they can be used by the broad scientific community. The new heat-flow probes will be lighter and provide near-real-time temperature data; both of which will streamline how heat flow data currently are collected. The project incorporates new technology into the prototypes compared to conventional heat flow probes. The project includes international collaboration and provides training for an undergraduate student.


This project aims to provide either real-time or near-real time temperature data at higher sample rates and with longer endurance time than standard heat flow probes. The prototypes have the potential to transform our understanding of complex submarine fluid flow near faults, seeps, vent sites, or caldera lakes. The two prototype probes are designed to operate in water depths of 500 m (Prototype-1) and 2000 m (Prototype-2); individual components for each probe have been pressure tested. Currently, however, the fully constructed probes are untested at pressures greater than 1 MPa (100 m water depth). Prototype-1 is designed to include real-time heat flow data and sea-bottom imaging for site characterization and selection; Prototype-2 is designed with Bluetooth data transmission. Both prototypes will increase heat flow data collection by a factor of two compared to conventional methods. Until pressure tests and geothermal gradient field tests are completed, however, the probes cannot be scheduled for scientific use without high risk of failure. This study has the potential to transform how marine heat flow and fluid fluxes are collected and analyzed, especially in high heat flow environments. Work involves full pressure testing and potential thermal gradient testing for prototype-2. Specifically, the pressure tests will go to 20 MPa (up to 2000 m water depth), and the thermistors will be tested offshore Montserrat.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Heat Flow (the amount of heat energy emitted from Earth's surface) represents a fundamental geophysical property that provides important insight into planetary evolution, plate tectonics, subsurface fluid flow, and climate change. Heat flow measurements also provide critical insight into important societal questions associated with groundwater flow, contamination, hydrocarbon formation/mobilization, pore-pressure, slope stability, and geothermal energy development. Unfortunately, the tools required to measure heat flow are often large, cumbersome, and expensive. For example, in marine settings, the primary tools used to measure heat flow offshore are either (1) thermometers deployed down boreholes drilled into the seafloor using a drillship, or (2) thermometers lanced into the shallow seafloor using an approximately 0.5 -1 ton, 3-m long steel lance. Each of these approaches typically requires several hours or days (if drilling is necessary) of ship time using large research vessels that routinely cost more than $40,000 a day to operate.  Additionally, processing heat flow data typically takes hours to days--neither approach provides real-time data so often needed while on site.  Finally, the potential for damaging equipment when making these measurements is high, since the thermistors are often inserted into the seafloor under high pressures and at high velocities to ensure good coupling/penetration. When these instruments are damaged, costs can exceed hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost time and equipment. Due to the significant cost and complexity necessary to collect quality heat flow measurements, relatively few heat flow measurements are made by both industry and the scientific community.

The goal of this study was to test a pair of newly developed, portable, low-cost heat flow probe prototypes designed to make heat flow measurement in marine environments significantly more cost and time efficient.  Specifically, the new probes are designed for deployment by one or two people on a small boat (without a crane) in less than half the time and at a cost two- to three-orders of magnitude less than traditional methods.  Additionally, unlike past tools, the new probes provide real-time on-site data at higher spatial resolution. To achieve these objectives, the probes are designed to be expendable and quickly replaceable, with each constructed from low cost, off-the-shelf components. The probes are lightweight (less than 25 lbs as opposed to ~1 ton), and highly transportable, so that they can easily be shipped and used on any research vessel of opportunity. The probes are also outfitted with either a data cable or Bluetooth so that data can be transmitted near real-time. If or when the probes break due to impact with the seafloor, another can be deployed in less than 15 minutes. The thermistors in the probe have also been injected with high-conductivity epoxy, that enables the probe to collect steady-state temperature data in about half the time necessary compared to convention probes (~3 minutes as opposed to 7 minutes). Perhaps most importantly, however, because the probes are lightweight and expendable, they can be deployed from much smaller vessels, so that ship costs are significantly reduced. For example, during one of our probe tests, we used a 20 foot vessel that cost $300/day to make 30 heat flow measurements in 3 hours in approximately 50 meters of water. Collecting these same data using a traditional Lister-style heat flow probe would have required a ship with a day rate cost of ~$10,000/day, a crew of 2-3 additional personnel, while providing no real-time data.

Two versions of the probe exist: the first uses a Bluetooth transmitter and can be connected to a cable or rope and deployed to a depth up to 2100 m. The second version of the probe has a combined dataline/strength member attached to the probe head, and can be deployed to a depth of 500 m. For this research study, we successfully tested the probe at three sites: (1) a Texas lake to a depth of 10 m, (2) the Caribbean Sea to a depth of 1000 meters, and (3) Mono Lake (California) to a depth of 50 meters.  Our results demonstrate that these new probes provide a valuable, lower risk, cost/time efficient approach for collecting marine heat flow data.  Future research will improve the housing and depth rating of these probes and their potential as possible long-term heat/fluid flow monitoring systems. Details of the probe design were published this past year in the following journal:

Hornbach, M.J., Sylvester, J., Hayward, C., Kuhn, M., Huhn‐Frehers, K., Freudenthal, T., Watt, S.F., Berndt, C., Kutterolf, S., Kuhlmann, J. and Sievers, C., 2021. A Hybrid Lister‐Outrigger probe for rapid marine geothermal gradient measurement. Earth and Space Science, 8(1), p.e2020EA001327.
